column5: So as I gather with Montanans from all over the state, I'm pleased to say as I have before that the transfer of federal lands to the state will never happen, "Not On Our Watch!"
We cannot and we must not let anyone or any corporate interest try to transfer or sell off our public lands, or jeopardize our quality of life and what it means to be a Montanan.
We cannot and we must not leave to our kids and grandkids anything less than the unrivaled outdoor experience and heritage that our parents and grandparents worked so hard to preserve for us.
We must continue to build up our voices to be even louder - so that when misguided politicians try to threaten our public lands, they can't break through our noise.
But make no mistake, the attacks on our public lands are real and we must continue to speak with one loud voice to protect them.
Our public lands are our great equalizer. No matter who you are, where you're from, how much money you have, each and every one of us equally own these public lands.

Right now I'm gathered with hundreds of Montanans from all corners of our state to rally in support of our public lands. This isn't the first time we've gathered to #KeepItPublic and it won't be the last. https://t.co/QuckAkK8uW

As we work together this session to continue providing healthcare for 95,000 of our friends and neighbors, let's not forget the larger impact on our businesses, workers, and Montana's economy.

Medicaid expansion benefits businesses in all 56 counties across Montana and in every industry. 57% of private Montana businesses have at least one employee enrolled in Medicaid expansion. That's 18,000 businesses all across the state.
It's time we fully recognize that the value of Medicaid expansion is as much for our Montana businesses as it is for the Montanans now receiving access to health care.
On the second day of #mtleg, I released a new report that shows how Medicaid expansion benefits businesses, workers and Montana's economy.

On this one year anniversary of the vote to repeal #NetNeutrality, my invitation still stands. Any state can protect the internet as we know it and you can find the template to do it here: https://t.co/xMfEZCOXY5
I ended up signing an executive order to protect net neutrality in Montana and invited other states and governors to join us.
At first I told her as a governor there was nothing I could do, but then I started thinking about it.
She had called Montana's congressional delegation, and now she was calling me. She wanted to know what we were going to do to protect a free and open internet.
Once it sunk in that the FCC was trying to gut one of society's great equalizers, I got a phone call that my teenage daughter, Caroline, was calling my main office switchboard.
One year ago today, the FCC voted to repeal #NetNeutrality. Net neutrality makes sure we all have equal footing to start a business, get an education, and connect with the world.

I’m optimistic that come January, all of us – Democrats and Republicans – will come to Helena, roll up our sleeves and get to work. Together we can ensure Montana continues on a great path.
I believe this budget reflects not only my priorities as Governor, but more importantly, the priorities of the people of the great state of Montana.

In order to preserve the progress we’ve made across the state, especially in rural communities, I’m proposing to fully fund Medicaid expansion to continue healthcare for nearly 100,000 Montanans. There’s too much at stake not to keep Medicaid expansion going in Montana.

I am proposing to make sustainable investments in critical infrastructure across our state - in urban and rural communities - essential to our continued economic growth and to creating a future for Montana that our kids can build their families and lives in.

I am proposing to expand our investment in high-quality, affordable preschool, to once again freeze college tuition in our university system, and to join every other state in offering need-based financial aid.

I expect the 2019 legislature to work with me on what, at their core, should not be partisan issues when it comes to our budget. And in addition to being fiscally sound, work with me to address issues and priorities Montanans care about.
Montanans understand the importance of leaving money in the bank for unexpected things that might come our way. It’s not just good policy, it’s the fiscally responsible thing to do.
Montanans are best served when we work together, regardless of political party, on a budget that is not only balanced, but also funds essential services Montanans expect.
I’m optimistic that in Montana we can still be a shining example for the country of how our political system is supposed to work.
Today I'm releasing my budget for consideration by the 2019 #mtleg. The budget I present is a reflection of the values we hold dear as Montanans.
